QuestionStem: Explore the photos to learn more about some animals’ migration patterns.

images.caption: Monarch butterflies travel from the United States to Mexico to avoid the cold winter temperatures.
images.altText: In this photograph, many monarch butterflies move through the air as a group.

images.caption: The arctic tern makes the longest known annual migration—from the South Pole to the North Pole and back again.
images.altText: In this photograph, a large group of white birds is in the process of landing on the ground.

images.caption: Salmon are hatched in fresh water and then migrate to the ocean. When salmon are ready to reproduce, they migrate back to the freshwater areas where they were hatched.
images.altText: In this photograph, a large group of salmon are moving through water.

images.caption: This gray whale and her calf are migrating north from California to summer feeding grounds in the Arctic.
images.altText: In this photograph, an adult whale and a young whale move through ocean water.
